awd_titl_txt: Quantum State Engineering with Novel Nonlinear Interferometric Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
Classical physics underpins many of the technological advances in computers, optical communications, and mobile devices that have made profound impacts in daily life, the economy, and society. However, as technology pushes forward, following Moore's law in computer engineering, it is gradually reaching limits where classical physics will no longer suffice.  At this point, electrical and optical engineers will need to use quantum physics, which, up to the end of 20th century, had been mostly the subject of fundamental study.  A key component for quantum technologies will be the ability to engineer quantum states of light, or photons.  This research project will address the problem of quantum state engineering by exploring new ways to control the shape of single-photon quantum states using quantum interference.  Because single-photon states are a basic building block for quantum technologies, this project will support the development of practical and versatile quantum devices for applications such as quantum information processing.  The table-top experiments in this project are also an ideal platform for training and preparing next generation quantum physicists.  Undergraduate students and graduate students will be involved in this research program.  This project will deepen their understanding of quantum physics, which in turn will promote further applications using quantum interference techniques.

Photon indistinguishability is essential to achieve complete quantum interference, which is the key in many protocols in optical quantum information processing with linear optical elements.  The achievement of photon indistinguishability in experiments is through mode matching of photon states. While spatial modes of optical fields are relatively easy to manage, the temporal modes are much more complicated, especially for ultra-short pulses. In this research program, this team will employ a recently developed nonlinear quantum interferometric technique to achieve custom engineering of the spectral and temporal modes of the quantum states produced from ultra-fast nonlinear optical interactions. The essence of the technique is in the manipulation of the spectral phase shift that controls the nonlinear interaction via quantum interference and leads to interference filtering and eventually engineering of the spectral profiles of the output states for single mode operation. This team will implement the technique experimentally and demonstrate its effectiveness with a multi-photon interference experiment to achieve the efficient production of transform-limited single-photon states in single modes. Quantum state engineering is important for experimental implementations of quantum information protocols. It can be used to tailor the temporal modes of the optical fields to fit the experimental requirement and thus has very practical significance in the study of quantum information processing. This investigation provides a new approach for quantum state engineering.

This project is jointly funded by the Quantum Information Science (QIS) Program in the Physics Division in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate, and the Electronics, Photonics and Magnetic Devices (EPMD) Program in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems Division in the Engineering Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the NSF supporting period, we mainly made comprehensive studies in both theory and experiment on two topics of “spectral engineering of two-photon states” and “temporal profiles of a quantum device known as optical parametric amplifier”.

On the first topic of spectral engineering of two-photon states, we adopted the method of quantum interference to engineer the spectral correlation properties of the photon states. The control is through programable phase change to either introduce constructive (positive) or destructive (negative) interference (change) at specific wavelengths to engineer the shape to what we want. We made a comprehensive theoretical study on this method and guide experimental efforts to successfully achieve the required properties.

A particular example is the single temporal mode quantum source, which is highly desirable in quantum information sciences and quantum-enhanced precision measurement. The single-mode nature is crucial for high visibility in quantum interference of independent sources, which is the fundamental process and building block in all quantum information protocols and quantum metrology. Compared to other methods, which are usually fixed once done, our approach is simple and versatile, and can be tailored to applications such quantum spectroscopy where specific spectral quantum correlation is needed for increasing both temporal and spectral resolution.

The general design concept can also be applied to other areas such as integrated optics for manufacturing nano-scale quantum sources for integrated quantum systems. Once the single-mode quantum sources are developed, we anticipate its wide application in the newly emerging quantum technology, which is superior to the current classical technology and can significantly improve the daily life.

On the second topic of temporal profiles of quantum optical parametric amplifiers, which usually have complicated quantum entanglement in spectral domain. We simplified the entangled correlation by analyzing in temporal domain and found and implemented an iteration method to sort out the eigen-modes (those that keep the temporal shape unchanged through amplification). We improve on the method by using stimulated emission from two-seed injection, which works for high gain but also for the low gain case when the original method fails. We simulated the mode structure of high-gain parametric processes and explored how it changes with the gain.

Parametric amplifiers are popular sources of quantum states such as two-photon states, squeezed states and entangled states, which have wide applications in quantum information, quantum communication and quantum sensing. Knowledge of the mode structure is extremely important for achieving single-mode operation, which is a must for fundamental quantum interference processes occurring in almost all quantum phenomena. The confirmation of the single-mode operation of the source was usually done by applying the cumbersome quantum interference technique. Our approach is simple and straightforward, and is perfect for characterizing quantum sources which usually has very low photon flux. It should have wide application in ultra-fast field, quantum optics and quantum information for the characterization of the eigen mode structure of basically any pulse-pumped system.

Through this project, we have trained future quantum physicists and prepared them for the upcoming second quantum revolution. One graduate student obtained his Ph.D. degree and moved on for his post-doctorial training; two high-school students participated and learned quantum physics in the project. The work is disseminated through nine journal publications and eight conference presentations.
